evidence: When a proton with a magnetic moment is placed in a strong external magnetic field, its behavior becomes quantized.
quantum mechanics tells us that only certain orientations are allowed.
the nuclear magnetic quantum number, m I, which for a proton can be plus one-half or minus one-half.
we focus on the longitudinal component of the magnetic moment
gamma times Planck’s constant divided by four pi
the fundamental energy levels we use in MRI

triples.evidence: the z-component of the magnetic moment, μz, equals plus or minus gamma times Planck’s constant divided by four pi. This means the magnetic moment is never perfectly aligned-it is always tilted slightly. But it is restricted to these two possible states.

concepts.term: These values are determined by the nuclear magnetic quantum number, m I, which for a proton can be plus one-half or minus one-half.

evidence: So, the z-component of the magnetic moment, miu z, equals plus or minus gamma times Planck's constant divided by four pi.
triples.o: plus or minus gamma times Planck's constant divided by four pi
triples.s: the z-component of the magnetic moment, miu z
